mainClaim: Space exploration generates massive economic returns and drives critical technological innovation
evidence: NASA economic analysis shows every $1 invested returns $7-14 in economic activity through technology transfer. GPS (space tech) generates $1.4 trillion annually in economic value. Space program spinoffs include: memory foam, cordless tools, water filtration, satellite communications, weather forecasting (saves $31 billion/year in disaster prevention). Current space economy is $469 billion, projected to reach $1.8 trillion by 2035, creating 1.5 million high-skill jobs.
supportingPoints: Asteroid mining could unlock quadrillions in rare earth minerals
Space manufacturing enables materials impossible to create in gravity
Climate monitoring satellites essential for understanding/addressing climate change
Inspirational value drives STEM education and long-term innovation culture
limitations: Returns are long-term and uncertain. Opportunity cost compared to direct Earth-focused research. Private sector now capable of many space activities. Equitable distribution of space economy benefits not guaranteed.
